prompt: How are dividends taxed in canada for individuals
orig_response: In Canada, dividends received by individuals are subject to taxation, but they benefit from a preferential tax treatment known as the dividend tax credit. There are two types of dividends: eligible and non-eligible. Eligible dividends, typically paid by public corporations or large private corporations, are grossed up by 38% before being included in taxable income, and individuals can claim a federal dividend tax credit of 15.0198% on the grossed-up amount. Non-eligible dividends, usually paid by small businesses, are grossed up by 15% and come with a lower federal tax credit of 9.0301%. This system effectively reduces the overall tax burden on dividend income compared to regular interest income, encouraging investment in Canadian corporations. Additionally, provincial tax rates and credits may also apply, further influencing the effective tax rate on dividends.
